update.description:
This pull request generalizes the classes for computing flow properties and CFL.  

The flow properties are generalized to take arbitrary strings (-> operator trees), and the corresponding global min, max, and grid averages are computed and accessed using the property name.  An additional method has been added for computing the volume average of a flow property.

The CFL class is generalized to accept arbitrary frequencies, velocities along any axis, and sets of velocities for use in computing a limiting timestep.  Additionally it allows you to easily add constraints on the max/min timestep and max/min timestep ratio (compared to previous timestep).  The limiting timestep is still computed as the inverse of the global maximum of the sum of the provided frequencies on the dealiased grid.

The RB example has been updated to show how to use both of these new features.
update.title: Flow tools generalization

The flow properties are generalized to take arbitrary strings (-> operator trees), and the corresponding global min, max, and grid averages are computed and accessed using the property name.  An additional method has been added for computing the volume average of a flow property.

The CFL class is generalized to accept arbitrary frequencies, velocities along any axis, and sets of velocities for use in computing a limiting timestep.  Additionally it allows you to easily add constraints on the max/min timestep and max/min timestep ratio (compared to previous timestep).  The limiting timestep is still computed as the inverse of the global maximum of the sum of the provided frequencies on the dealiased grid.

The RB example has been updated to show how to use both of these new features.
update.title: Flow tools generalization

content.raw:
Just tested this (https://bitbucket.org/bpbrown/anelastic_polytrope) and it looks great. Timesteps look correct, flows look right too.  

I vote we merge.
content.html:
Just tested this (https://bitbucket.org/bpbrown/anelastic_polytrope) and it looks great. Timesteps look correct, flows look right too.

I vote we merge.

content.raw:
All,
    I'll see if I can take a look at it tomorrow afternoon.

--Ben
content.html:
All, I'll see if I can take a look at it tomorrow afternoon.

--Ben

content.raw:
Thanks for taking a look.
1) Yeah that's a good idea, I'll add it in and update the PR.
2)  There's an infinite number of ways to combine the individual frequencies to compute a global one, and it would be great to see an in-depth analysis of how to best compute the CFL for a spectral code... but in the absence of real evidence as to the best way to do it, I think it makes sense to opt for the simplest choice and treat all timescales equally.  In any case it probably shouldn't make a big difference... it will always be dominated by the fastest timescale and this method just gives a little more padding when there are other important timescales, as well.
content.html: Thanks for taking a look. 1) Yeah that's a good idea, I'll add it in and update the PR. 2) There's an infinite number of ways to combine the individual frequencies to compute a global one, and it would be great to see an in-depth analysis of how to best compute the CFL for a spectral code... but in the absence of real evidence as to the best way to do it, I think it makes sense to opt for the simplest choice and treat all timescales equally. In any case it probably shouldn't make a big difference... it will always be dominated by the fastest timescale and this method just gives a little more padding when there are other important timescales, as well.

content.raw:
Finally looked at this...  I would say that it looks pretty good, but I have two comments.

First, for taking volume averages, could we put the integrate(field) into the self.properties evaluator?  This seems more efficient.  Maybe under "add_property" add an option saying that you're going to want to know the integral of the field.

Second, I don't know if we really want to add up all the frequencies for the CFL calculation.  Adding the frequencies makes sense for something like delta x/u + delta y/v + delta z/w, but not if you have a bunch of other unrelated timescales.  What if every time you add a new frequency, a new velocity, or new velocities, we made a new handler.  Then you can add up all the frequencies for each handler, and then take the max over the frequencies of each handler?
content.html:
Finally looked at this... I would say that it looks pretty good, but I have two comments.

First, for taking volume averages, could we put the integrate(field) into the self.properties evaluator? This seems more efficient. Maybe under "add_property" add an option saying that you're going to want to know the integral of the field.

Second, I don't know if we really want to add up all the frequencies for the CFL calculation. Adding the frequencies makes sense for something like delta x/u + delta y/v + delta z/w, but not if you have a bunch of other unrelated timescales. What if every time you add a new frequency, a new velocity, or new velocities, we made a new handler. Then you can add up all the frequencies for each handler, and then take the max over the frequencies of each handler?

This pull request generalizes the classes for computing flow properties and CFL.  

The flow properties are generalized to take arbitrary strings (-> operator trees), and the corresponding global min, max, and grid averages are computed and accessed using the property name.  An additional method has been added for computing the volume average of a flow property.

The CFL class is generalized to accept arbitrary frequencies, velocities along any axis, and sets of velocities for use in computing a limiting timestep.  Additionally it allows you to easily add constraints on the max/min timestep and max/min timestep ratio (compared to previous timestep).  The limiting timestep is still computed as the inverse of the global maximum of the sum of the provided frequencies on the dealiased grid.

The RB example has been updated to show how to use both of these new features.
